attachments.title: A Slick New Bike With Buzzing Handlebars That Give You Directions | WIRED
attachments.text: Its gutsBAD+2s—the wires, shifters, brake cables—are housed in a 3-D printed titanium frame.

text: makes me wish I had pushed harder to get the patent on those...
it's pretty cool you can add them to any bike
I’d love to test-drive them. The issue we had was being able to feel them on PDX’s crappy streets with all the road vibe

attachments.title: An Analog Activity Tracker Isn't as Ridiculous as It Sounds | WIRED
attachments.text: Emulsion is a provocative reminder that you don't need expensive electronics to be be mindful of your activity.
attachments.fallback: WIRED: An Analog Activity Tracker Isn't as Ridiculous as It Sounds | WIRED

text: feel like i need to get to know this papenek character: Indeed, the designers describe Emulsion as an attempt to take a “Victor Papanek approach” to fitness tracking. Papanek, an influential design theorist, was an acerbic critic of consumer culture and mainstream industrial design. (Sample quote: “There are professions more harmful than industrial design, but only a very few of them.”) Papanek, who lived for long stretches in developing countries and among native tribes, condemned what he saw as wasteful, needlessly high-tech solutions to simple problems.
though - for my money, I’ve always felt his frustrations with design misplaced anger towards capitalism broadly and commercialization specifically.
Also keep in mind he’s post-war europe. He’s thoughts fall very squarely into the modernist world-view
